channel.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
channel.description:
Hey,
I'm only going into my freshman year in highschool, but I'm usually the type of person that likes to prepare for everything. Since I was nine years old my dream was to become a software engineer. I know a few languages, and I'm learning more right now. But, I just wanted to know peoples opinions on the best schools for this subject. I want to get my masters in computer programming. I get 8 free years tuition to any school in the US, so don't worry about prices. Location isn't an issue either, as long as it is in the US. Anyways, post your opinions.
Thanks,
Buzzy

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Actually SATs don’t mean much of anything, it is all in the ACT. (most colleges don’t even want SATs anymore)

I don’t know what your talking about tbh. Because more students take the SAT, it is more important when measuring against other students. When admissions officers are more interested in comparing student x to student y, odds are, both students took the SAT. Therefore, they can accurately measure aptitude with SAT than ACT.

Of course, SAT measures more of how little friends you have, not exactly how well you’ll do in college, but whatever. The entire college admissions process is broken, standardized tests are only moreso.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“leader, post:20, topic:133826”]If you want to go to a good University follow what is mentioned below.

Aim for all A’s. Take the highest classes available for you. Try keep your gpa over 4.0. Get good sat scores. Do sports and join some clubs. Do voluntary work.[/quote]

Most important thing is find something that you’re passionate about. Computers, Greek, molecular biology, etc. Despite what your teachers and parents tell you, colleges don’t want a well-rounded student. They want one who is passionate about one thing. They don’t want a jack of all trades, master of none. They want someone who is focused and takes initiative. Sports aren’t as important for Ivy Leagues, unless you are a pro and have grades to back it up. Ivy Leagues can only bend so far to pick up a star athlete. And tbh, GPA is so subjective. Just shoot for all A+'s if you school has them, and if you fall short, maybe you’ll end up with only A’s? Set high goals. SAT’s are important. They are the ultimate leveler, and the only way to improve your score is by brute force taking tests and analyzing each answer.

Yea, just all my regrets from high school.

Read full topic

If you want to go to a good University follow what is mentioned below.

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:15, topic:133826”][quote author=1337h4x link=topic=185099.msg1676931#msg1676931 date=1187211844]
I’m gonna try for MIT, I really don’t think I’ll make it though… :[
[/quote]

Age, grade, location, gpa, class rank, and sat scores (if applicable)?[/quote]I’m just going to high school, so none of that gpa/rank/sat crap.

14, going to 9th, Hinsdale, Illinois. Going to central which is one of the best high schools out there. Got straight A’s 6th and 7th grade, during 8th had a mix of A’s and B’s ( max 2 b’s per quarter ), 3rd report card was all B’s and one C :[

The last was a a couple A’s and rest B’s pretty bad, but better then last report card >.>

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

MIT Institutional Research

MIT Institutional Research

MIT Institutional Research

Scroll down to C9.

On the SAT’s, the middle 50% of students got a 660-760 Critical Reading score and a 720-800 Math score. So start working towards those 4’s. And you need to be excellent otherwise; as you’ve heard, SAT’s aren’t everything, i.e. I got a 770 CR and 800 M (higher than 75% of their matriculating class), and I don’t think I stand a chance applying to MIT.

You’ve gotta be mad intense. Discover a new bacterium, start a web developing business with decent profits. Something like that.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Before college, I had always wanted to become a mechanical engineer, but after 2 years of college and ‘Differential Equations for Engineers’, which comes after the second worst class of Calculus 2. I discovered that I would be just as happy majoring in Computer science, and would start out making about $30,000 dollars more a year than with a mechanical engineering degree. So I switched majors and will therefore have to take an extra semester, but I guess in the end it will be worth it. Good luck in whatever you choose

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

BobDole81:

I don’t remember mentioning Princeton

Indirectly:

BobDole81:

Another family friend recommended against going to Harvard (where he attended for undergrad), or any of the highfalutin ivy leagues (and their competitors) unless you absolutely know what you want to do.

And yea, I suppose it is important to know what you’re doing. But tbh I have honestly no clue, and if I settled for something now, I’ll probably change it later on.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

xxlegitxx:

I thought Princeton didn’t allow you to pick a major until junior year?

I don’t remember mentioning Princeton

But when applying for colleges, you do have to put down a tentative major (most colleges have an undecided option). The first year, I believe, is mostly spent doing general courses and courses of personal interest…Cornell emphasizes the latter, and recommends going through their course catalog and just picking random courses that appeal to you for the first year.

What I meant about knowing what you want to do is that if you have a major/career plan in mind, you can choose the major you are going to stick with earlier on, and you can take advantage of internship, co-op, and research opportunities earlier as opposed to waiting when you do know what to do. For most colleges, I would imagine that this is not a big deal - you have a few years to make up your mind and decided what to do. But the upper colleges have such a competitive student body, that it is apparently difficult to do that (as I mentioned, this is what I was told…this part is not from experience).

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:7, topic:133826”]I was accepted into CMU (College of Sciences, not CS), but I didn’t try MIT. CMU’s school of Computer Science is one of the best in the country. Spaces are extremely limited and there is huge competition to get in. In my ignorance, in my application I put down the school of CS as my second choice (as I didn’t know what else to choose), and I was immediately rejected As for MIT, a family friend of ours did his graduate work at MIT and recommended against going there, saying that students are so overworked that undergrads literally have no life beyond school.

Another family friend recommended against going to Harvard (where he attended for undergrad), or any of the highfalutin ivy leagues (and their competitors) unless you absolutely know what you want to do. If you are decided on the relative path that you want to take for your degree and career, then those colleges will be able to provide countless opportunities. But if you’re relatively undecided, he said, then you really won’t enjoy it. [/quote]

I thought Princeton didn’t allow you to pick a major until junior year?

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I was accepted into CMU (College of Sciences, not CS), but I didn’t try MIT. CMU’s school of Computer Science is one of the best in the country. Spaces are extremely limited and there is huge competition to get in. In my ignorance, in my application I put down the school of CS as my second choice (as I didn’t know what else to choose), and I was immediately rejected As for MIT, a family friend of ours did his graduate work at MIT and recommended against going there, saying that students are so overworked that undergrads literally have no life beyond school.

Another family friend recommended against going to Harvard (where he attended for undergrad), or any of the highfalutin ivy leagues (and their competitors) unless you absolutely know what you want to do. If you are decided on the relative path that you want to take for your degree and career, then those colleges will be able to provide countless opportunities. But if you’re relatively undecided, he said, then you really won’t enjoy it.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @Buzzy Buzzy
item.description:
@Buzzy wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:2, topic:133826”]In no particular order:

[ul][]MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
[] CMU (Carnegie Mellon)
[] University of California, Berkeley
[] Stanford
[*] CalTech (California Institute of Technology)[/ul]

Those are amongst the most famous and well recognized schools for computer science. I myself was seriously looking into going into CS/IS a while ago. I’d recommend spending the next few years improving your computing skills and pick a language (preferably C/C++) to learn in depth…you may find that you’ll change your mind about going into CS like I did :P[/quote]
Thanks a lot. Time to research them now, and find which one I like more. It’s funny you should speak of C++ because that is the one I’m learning now.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Colleges For Computer Programming
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

In no particular order:

[ul][]MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
[] CMU (Carnegie Mellon)
[] University of California, Berkeley
[] Stanford
[*] CalTech (California Institute of Technology)[/ul]

Those are amongst the most famous and well recognized schools for computer science. I myself was seriously looking into going into CS/IS a while ago. I’d recommend spending the next few years improving your computing skills and pick a language (preferably C/C++) to learn in depth…you may find that you’ll change your mind about going into CS like I did

Read full topic
